fields.Title of Presentation: “The Green in Red: Cochineal in the Divine Weeks of Du Bartas”
fields.Description/Abstract: Edward M. Test’s paper, “Royal Red: Cochineal and the Natural New World,” explores the myths and markets surrounding the premier red dye of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, cochineal (or crimson), which existed only in Mexico. Prior to the discovery of the New World, the red dye favored by European aristocrats and clergy (the primary consumers of vermillion) was the kermes “grain,” which like Cochineal was really an insect.
